author: @bhaskargundu2014
text: tty="terminal type" .............. the origin of this  was unix  , where , the unix server does not care for the power of the client, but dictates as to when and how it time-slices the task as per its scheduler running in its server's kernel, and the clients could even be "dumb terminals" (hence , sometimes, "virtual terminals" [with less cpu power and no secondary storage, but just a keyboard and a monitor , the cpu used to come as part of the base of the Monitor/CRT device] like "VT 100", "ET 3000" etc.) ofcourse , the game changed with "Networking Operating Systems" , like Novell Netware,Windows NT etc. , where , the task is distributed among server and client, and hence, the more mature the client, the better the client's performance -------- the client / server architecture, hence, the clients have been desktops/laptops/.....smart devices etc.

author: @poopipeboy3033
text: DO NOT GET A GTX 650!!  Here's why.... I tested computing time of the deep-net example program on different hardware, and these are my results:      Intel Xeon E5450 3GHz = 2 min 1 sec      Nvidia GTX 650 1GB = 53 sec      Nvidia GT 730 2GB = 40 sec      Nvidia GT 1030 2GB = 19 sec I verified these results through multiple runs, rebooting and double-checking the code. Just forget about old GTX cards and go straight for a cheap ~$80 GT 1030 that will deliver modern compute performance.

author: @peterkmm100
text: 15 month later, its fair to state that 4 GB RAM on a GPU are pretty much the entry standard (im using  GTX 960 'maxwell' cc_5.2, 4 GB and an older 'kepler' chip, cc_3.5). The mainstream GeForce GTX 1060s ship with 6 GB priced around 270 € here in Germany, while the 8 GB GTX 1080s cost 500 €. I`d say most people now have either 4 GB or 6 GB of memory available to store data on their GPUs. Beside buying a GPU with huge memory (and big price tag), a great option to learn is consider using the AWS GPU cloud instance! Thats cheap and convenient, too!

text: The Tensorflow GPU version is now directly available for Windows. Tested and working on Win 8.1, Anaconda, Pycharm.  pip install tensorflow-gpu is the only command that is required. Make sure to install the CUDA toolkit and setup the cuDNN prior to installing the gpu version.
